Faculty of Electrical and Electronic Engineering

analytic.title: Applied Mathematics and Computation

biblStruct.note: Received 6 August 2019 Revised 4 April 2020 Accepted 11 April 2020

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Fractional-order hyperchaotic memristor oscillator Fractional-order robust adaptive controller Sliding mode-based adaptation mechanism Voice encryption

div.p: The present study proposes a new fractional-order hyperchaotic memristor oscillator. The proposed system is studied through numerical simulations and analyses, such as the Lyapunov exponents, bifurcation diagrams, and phase portraits. Then, using the sliding mode concept, a robust adaptive control scheme is designed to synchronize the proposed system. The adaptation mechanism is implemented to estimate the unknown parameters of the slave system. Then, the output of the proposed adaptation mechanism is used for the control scheme. The stability of the closed-loop system is proven via a fractional version of the Lyapunov stability theorem and Barbalat's lemma. Numerical simulations of synchronization are shown to investigate the performance of the developed control technique on the uncertain fractional-order hyperchaotic memristor oscillator. Finally, as an engineering application, the proposed fractional-order system is implemented for voice encryption. In this regard, to show the appropriate performance of the proposed system for voice encryption, statistical characteristic of the encryption and decryption processes are performed through different methods including correlation, entropy, root mean square, and root sum of squares.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Over the past decades, chaos and its applications have attracted remarkable consideration in a variety of fields [1] . The high sensitivity to the system parameters, variations of the environmental situation, and initial conditions are some features of chaotic systems. Due to the importance of chaos and its influence in the variety of fields, the behaviors of these systems have been extensively studied [2][3][4][5] .

The memristor, as the fourth element in electronic circuits, was theoretically introduced by Chua [6] . The first practical implementation was introduced by HP in 2008 [7] . Due to the attractive characteristics of memristors (non-volatility, reprogrammability, and analog storage properties), these systems have been used for many applications in different areas such as neural networks, sound encryption, neuromorphic computation and memristor-based circuits [8][9][10][11][12] . Besides, the memristor has been thoroughly studied as a nonlinear element to generate chaotic behavior, resulting in the well-known memristive chaotic systems [ 13 , 14 ].

Fractional calculus has natural connections with many fields of applied physics and engineering. The ability to describe the hereditary characteristics of the system, as well as their memory, are the most important advantages of fractional calculus over integer calculus. Recently fractional calculus has been extensively used to model many systems in several fields, e.g. cyber-physical systems [15] , electromagnetic systems [ 16 , 17 ], viscoelastic damping [18] and control theory [ 19 , 20 ].

Coopmans et al. have studied the mathematical relation between the dynamical behavior and fractional-order derivative of the memristive system [21] . Petras has introduced a fractional-order flux-controlled memristor to generate chaos in modified Chua's oscillator [22] . Yu and Wang have illustrated that the fractional-order can be used to control the area of memristor hysteresis loops. That was associated with memory strength caused by fractional-order. In fact, it has been demonstrated that the fractional-order memristor has capacitive or inductive properties as the fractional-order changes [23] . The electrical characteristics and frequency of a fractional-order generalized memristor have been investigated in [24] . Also, the synthesis of a fractional-order memristor emulator circuit has been suggested in [25] .

Synchronization and control of chaotic systems have attracted significant interests in a variety of fields [26] . Since Carroll and Pecora have proposed the first technique for control of chaotic systems [27] , various control strategies have been presented for control of these systems [28][29][30][31][32] . Among the stated techniques, SMC gained significant attention due to its special property such as guaranteed stability, computational simplicity, and robustness against uncertainties [ 33 , 34 ]. Most systems in real applications possess complex nonlinear dynamics, which parameters of the system cannot be correctly known [ 35 , 36 ]. Also, due to environmental conditions, the features of the system may change. Therefore, it is beneficial to propose an adaptive sliding mode control (ASMC) for the synchronizing of uncertain systems [37] .

With the advent of new technologies, voice communications become more and more widely used and even more vulnerable [38] . Thereby, providing a high level of security has become a crucial concern in data communications [39] . In this regard, chaos-based cryptography has attracted a lot of attention due to its interesting features such as broadband power spectrum, extreme sensitivity to initial conditions, random-like behavior, and tolerance to sufficiently high levels of noise [ 40 , 41 ].

In most chaos-based encryption studies, integer-order chaotic systems have been used. However, fractional-order chaotic systems create extra parameters for security and expand the key space considerably. In comparison with integer-order chaotic systems, fractional-order ones show more complex characteristics and more degrees of freedom in the model due to the existence of fractional derivatives [ 42 , 43 ]. Also, it is clearly shown in the literature that the behaviors of fractional-order systems could dramatically change by altering the order of their derivatives [ 44 , 45 ]. Hence, by considering the derivative order as a free parameter to hide the portrait of a dynamical system, it is more challenging for an eavesdropper to delineate system type [46] . This way, fractional-order systems are more worthy candidates for encryption purposes. Nevertheless, there are a few research studies on voice encryption based on fractional-order chaoite systems [47] . For this reason, the new fractional-order chaotic system, which has been proposed in the current study, has been used in a voice encryption application. It is known that encryption applications are mostly on images. Therefore, fractional-order chaotic system-based voice encryption has been applied as a rare application in this study.

This article is motivated by investigating a new fractional-order hyperchaotic memristor oscillator. The behavior of the system has been studied with dynamical analysis. Also, an adaptive sliding mode method is developed for the synchronization of uncertain fractional-order systems. The adaptive mechanism has been combined with a sliding mode controller for synchronization of fractional-order systems. Actually, the current study has extended the adaptive mechanism in Ref. [48] by fractional-order calculus for the first time. Since it is assumed that the slave system is uncertain, its parameters are estimated during the control procedure by using a proper adaptive mechanism. The stability of the closed-loop system is proven via a fractional version of the Lyapunov stability theorem and Barbalat's lemma. Finally, considering the advantages of fractional-order systems for encryption, the new fractional-order system has been used for voice encryption, and statistical results of encryption have been illustrated.

The layout of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 , the fractional-order memristor system has been introduced, and the dynamical behaviors of this system have been thoroughly studied. The design procedure and stability proof of the ASMC have been presented in Section 3 . The simulation results of the synchronization are presented in Section 4 . Then, in Section 5 , an application of the proposed hyperchaotic system has been presented for voice encryption. Lastly, conclusions have been presented in Section 6 .

div.head: The memristor oscillator
div.p: The memristor was proposed by Chua as the fourth basic circuit element besides the three conventional electronic devices [6] . A memristor could represent the relation between the flux among the resistor, charge, inductor, and capacitor. This element can be defined by the following memristive system as [ 6 , 49 , 50 ]:
div.formula: ˙ w = Q ( u, w, t ) r = R ( u, w, t ) u ( t ) .
div.p: where u and r respectively are the input and output signals of the memristive system (1) . The state variable w is a ndimensional vector. Q (.) and R (.) are functions of state variables u and w . If the two variables u and r are considered as the voltage and current, respectively, then the relations can be defined as a charge-controlled memristive system or a fluxcontrolled memristive system [51] . A flux-controlled memristive system is used in the current study. The governing equation of this system is as follow:
div.formula: ⎧ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎩ ˙ x = a 1 ( y -x ) ˙ y = a 2 x -y -xz + a 3 w -T eq ˙ z = a 4 z + xy ˙ w = a 5 y + w + a 6 xM ( x ) (2)
div.p: where the state x is considered as the flux and M ( x ) = (0.1 + 0.5 x 2 ) represents the flux controlled memristor. The parameters of the system are considered as a 1 = 10, a 2 = 28, a 3 = 1, a 4 = -2, a 5 = 27, and a 6 = -1.

div.head: The fractional-order memristor system
div.p: In this section, the fractional-order form of the proposed system is derived. Fractional calculus is a generalization of the differentiation and integration to non-integer order, which is expressed by the continuous integro-differential operator a D q t , were a and t are the limits of the operation and q ∈ R . The three most frequently used definitions for the general fractional-order operator are Riemann-Liouville (RL), Grünwald-Letnikov (GL) and Caputo (C) [52] . Although the number of definitions is vast, not all of them are adequate to express the integro-differential operator, or for dealing with practical systems in compatibility with integer-order definitions. In this framework, Ortigueira and Tenreiro-Machado [53] proposed the strict sense criterion (SSC), an extension of the wide sense criterion (WSC), to determine if an operator can be classified as a Fractional Derivative or not, which is based on the criterion formulated by Ross [54] . The three definitions, RL, GL, and C, satisfy the mentioned criteria. For instance, C definition has been used to study fractional-order chaotic maps [ 55 , 56 ]; while RL was selected to investigate the fractional-order diffusion equation [57] . Additionally, from the point of view of applied sciences and signal processing, the GL fractional derivatives seem to be a natural way for generalizing the notion of derivative [ 52 , 57 , 58 ]. The GL definition has been addressed to analyze long memory process in industry [59] , fuzzy adaptive sliding mode control [60] , and FPGA-based implementations of chaotic oscillators [61] .

div.head: Proposed fractional-order memristor system and its numerical solution
div.p: From the seminal paper by Petras [22] , where reported the first paper on a memristor designed with fractional derivatives, some other works have been recently introduced [23][24][25] . Herein, the integer order four-dimensional system in ( 2) is generalized to the fractional-order domain by applying Caputo's definition of the fractional operator which is given by
div.formula: C 0 D q t f ( t ) = 1 ( m -q ) t ∫ 0 f ( m ) ( τ ) ( t -τ ) q -m +1 dτ,(3)
div.p: where m -1 < q < m , m ∈ N , q ∈ R + . Caputo's definition offers physically coherent meaning of initial conditions when solving corresponding fractional differential equations. Then, we obtain
div.formula: C 0 D q 1 t x = a 1 ( y -x ) C 0 D q 2 t y = a 2 x -y -xz + a 3 w -T eq C 0 D q 3 t z = a 4 z + xy C 0 D q 4 t w = a 5 y + w + a 6 xM ( x ) (4
div.p: where 0 < q i < 1, ( i = 1, 2, 3, 4) are the fractional-orders derivative of the equations. For the numerical calculation of the system (4) [62] , we use the GL definition given by
div.formula: GL D q t f ( t ) = lim | h | → 0 [ t-α h ] k =0 ( -1 ) k q k f ( t -kh ) | h | q , (5
div.p: where [ • ] means the integer part, α, and h are the bounds of the operation. Therefore, the numerical solution of the Fig. 2. Bifurcation diagram of the proposed fractional-order system for T eq with q = 0.9, and a 1 = 10.
div.formula: fractional differential equation GL D q t Y (t) = f ( Y (t) , t ) , can be expressed as Y ( t l ) = f ( Y ( t l-1 ) , t l-1 ) h q - l k =1 c ( q ) k Y ( t l-k ) .(6)
div.p: being t l = lh, h the time step, and c (q ) k the binomial coefficients, which can be calculated with c
Since the lower index of the sums in ( 6) is k = 1, the full memory is considered. Based on ( 6) , the solution of the system (4) is given by:
div.formula: x ( t l ) = [ a 1 ( y ( t l-1 ) -x ( t l-1 ) ) ] h q 1 - l k =1 c q 1 k x ( t l-k ) , y ( t l ) = [ a 2 x ( t l-1 ) -y ( t l-1 ) -x ( t l-1 ) z ( t l-1 ) + a 3 w ( t l-1 ) -T eq ] h q 2 - l k =1 c q 2 k y ( t l-k ) , z ( t l ) = [ a 4 z ( t l-1 ) + x ( t l-1 ) y ( t l-1 ) ] h q 3 - l k =1 c q 3 k z ( t l-k ) , w ( t l ) = [ a 5 y ( t l-1 ) + w ( t l-1 ) + a 6 x ( t l-1 ) M ( x ( t l-1 ) ) ] h q 4 - l k =1 c q 4 k w ( t l-k ) . (7)
div.p: Fig. 1 shows the numerical simulation results of the fractional-order system (4) by considering a commensurate fractional-order derivative. In this case, the parameter T eq defines the stability conditions of the fractional-order system. We observe the fractional-order generates a shrinking over the region where T eq was dominant. As can be seen in the bifurcation diagram of Fig. 2 , chaotic behavior is observed when -0.6 < T eq < 2.5. By selecting T eq = 0, we analyze the implications of the parameter a 1 in the chaotic behavior. Fig. 3 depicts the bifurcations of the parameter a 1 when T eq = -0.2, T eq = 0.2, T eq = 0, respectively. Contrary to the integer-order case, the chaotic behavior is suddenly found by means of a crisis scenario at a 1 = 2.6. Then a reverse process is observed where the chaotic attractor is again destroyed to be driven to unbounded solutions. Fig. 4 presents the bifurcations for the fractional-order. We observed the well-known antimonotonicity phenomenon for 0.97 < q < 0.99 where the fractional-order system gradually goes to chaos through a route of period doublings. When 0.83 < q < 0.97 complex behaviors are observed. Next, the chaotic behavior vanishes gradually for q < 0.83. As a result, the effective dimension which is the sum of the fractional-orders is as low as 3.32. Finally, in Fig. 5 , we present the Lyapunov exponents spectrum. The Wolf algorithm [63] , adopted for fractional-order systems [ 64 , 65 ], was used to compute the Lyapunov spectrum. The results show the chaotic behaviour is observed for q = 0.9 no matter the value of T eq . ( Fig. 5 a, 5 b, 5 c, and 5 e), whereas in Fig. 5 d we do not found chaotic oscillations since the fractional-order is q = 0.98.

div.head: Preliminaries
div.p: Based on Ref. [66] , the Lyapunov stability theorem for fractional-order systems is presented in Theorem 1 . Fig. 3. Bifurcations diagrams of the proposed fractional-order system for a 1 and q = 0.9 with (a) T eq = -0.2, (b) T eq = 0.2, and (c) T eq = 0.

Fig. 4. Bifurcations diagrams of the proposed fractional-order system for q and a 1 = 10, with (a) T eq = -0.2, (b) T eq = 0.2, and (c) T eq = 0. Theorem 1. [66] . Consider the generalized form of a nonlinear fractional-order system as C 0 D q t r ( t ) = f ( t, r ) (8) where q ∈ (0, 1) . If there exists a positive definite Lyapunov function V ( t, r ( t )) which fulfills the following inequality
div.formula: C 0 D q t V ( t , r ( t ) ) ≤ 0 (9)
div.p: as a result, the trajectories of the system are bounded, and the trivial solution of system ( 8) is asymptotically stable. Lemma 1. [67] . Consider f (t) ∈ R as a continuously differentiable function. As a result, for t ≥ t 0 we have:
Definition 1. [68] . For a function f ∈ L 1 ([ t 0 , T ]) the RL integral of order q > 0 and origin t 0 is defined as:
div.formula: 0 I q t f ( t ) = 1 ( q ) t ∫ t 0 ( t -τ ) q -1 f ( τ ) dτ, ∀ t ∈ ( t 0 , T ] . (11
div.p: Although different, the Caputo's derivative has the property of being the left inverse of the RL integral since
div.formula: C t 0 D q t t 0 I q t f (t) = f (t) .
div.p: Property 1. [69] . Where 0 < q < 1, the following equality holds for the Caputo derivative
div.formula: 0 I q t C 0 D q t f ( t ) = f ( t ) -f ( 0 ) . (12
div.p: According to Ref. [70] , Barbalat's Lemma for fractional -order nonlinear systems is as follow Theorem 2. [70] . Consider ψ as a continuous function.
div.formula: If t 0 I q t | ψ| a ≤ M for t > t 0 > 0, then lim t→∞ ψ ( t ) = 0 (13
div.p: where M and a are positive constants and q ∈ (0, 1) .

div.head: Controller design
div.p: The adaptive control strategy is an efficient methodology for synchronizing complex uncertain systems. We consider the case that the dynamic of the system is unknown. Also, it is assumed that the system is locally Lipschitz. The master system is considered as follow
Moreover, the slave system is
div.formula: C 0 D q t x i = f i ( t, X ) + u i ( t ) + d i ( t ) ( i = 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 ) (15)
div.p: where 0 < q < 1 denotes the fractional-order derivative of the equations. Y = [ y 1 ,…, y 4 ] T and X = [ x 1 ,…, x 4 ] T respectively are the measurable states of the master and slave system. g i (.) and f i (.) indicate nonlinear functions of the master and slave system Also, u i ( t ) and d i ( t ) are the control input and external disturbance, respectively. Throughout this article, it is assumed that all of the functions of the system are continuous derivative, and the states of the system are measurable. By defining the synchronization error as e i = x iy i ( i = 1, 2, 3, 4), we have
div.formula: C 0 D q t e i = f i ( t, Y ) + u i ( t ) + d i ( t ) -g i ( t, X ) ( i = 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 ) (16)
div.p: we consider that the unknown function f i could be defined as the product of a row matrix ( F i ) and the parameters vector ( A i ) as follow
div.formula: f i = F i A i (17
div.p: where the elements of F i are the nonlinear or linear functions of the states of the slave system. Also, A i is the parameter vector of the slave system. We assume that the unmodeled dynamics or disturbances are bounded, that is
div.formula: | d i | < d max i
div.p: . The sliding surface is considered as follow:
div.formula: s i ( t ) = e i (18) C 0 D q t s i ( t ) = C 0 D q t x i -C 0 D q t y i (19
div.p: Then, the adaptive sliding mode control tracking control is designed as
div.formula: u i = g i ( y ) -K i + d max 1 sign ( s i ) -F i Ā i (20
div.p: Moreover, the adaptation laws are
div.formula: C 0 D q t Ā i = P i F T i s i (21) C 0 D q t K i = δ i | s i | (22)
div.p: where δ i is a positive parameter and P i denotes a positive definite matrix of adaptation gains.
Theorem 3. By considering Eqs. ( 20) -( 22) , synchronization error (e i ) is bounded and converges to zero based on the proposed ASMC.
Proof. Let positive definite Lyapunov function candidate as:
div.formula: V 0 = 1 2 n i =1 s 2 i + ˜ A i P -1 i ˜ A i (23
div.p: where ˜
div.formula: A i = Ā i -A i .
div.p: According to Lemma 1 , a derivative of the Lyapunov function ( 23) is as follow:
div.formula: C 0 D q t V 0 = C 0 D q t 1 2 n i =1 s 2 i + ˜ A i P -1 i ˜ A i ≤ n i =1 s i C 0 D q t s i + C 0 D q t ˜ A i P -1 i ˜ A i = n i =1 s i C 0 D q t x i -C 0 D q t y i + C 0 D q t ˜ A i P -1 i ˜ A i = n i =1 s i ( d i ( x ) + f i ( x ) -g i ( y ) + u i ) + C 0 D q t ˜ A i P -1 i ˜ A i (24
div.p: Considering control law (20) , yields
div.formula: C 0 D q t V 0 = n i =1 s i d i ( x ) + f i ( x ) -g i ( x ) + g i ( x ) -K i + d max 1 sign ( s i ) -F i Ā i + C 0 D q t Ā i P -1 i ˜ A i = n i =1 s i d i ( x ) + f i ( x ) -K i + d max 1 sign ( s i ) -F i Ā i ) + C 0 D q t Ā i P -1 i ˜ A i (25
div.p: By rewriting the function f i ( x ) as the product of its corresponding row matrix and the vector of parameter ( f i ( x ) = F i A i ), and substituting the adaptation laws Eqs. ( 21) and ( 22) , we have
div.formula: C 0 D q t V 0 = n i =1 s i d i ( x ) -K i + d max 1 sign ( s i ) -F i ˜ A i ) + C 0 D q t Ā i P -1 i ˜ A i = n i =1 s i d i ( x ) -K i + d max 1 sign ( s i ) ) ≤ n i =1 -K i | s i | = n i =1 -δ i | s i | 2(26)
div.p: Therefore C 0 D q t V 0 ≤ 0 ; this way, based on Theorem 1 , s i and ˜ A i are bounded which means that the system states are bounded. By integrating both sides of Eq. ( 26) and considering Property 1 , one can achieve
div.formula: 0 I q t C 0 D q t V 0 = V 0 ( t ) -V 0 ( 0 ) ≤ - n i =1 δ i 0 I q t | s i | 2 → V 0 ( t ) + n i =1 δ i 0 I q t | s i | 2 ≤ V 0 ( 0 ) (27
div.p: Since the V 0 is a positive function, we have
div.formula: n i =1 δ i 0 I q t | s i | 2 ≤ V 0 ( 0 ) → n i =1 0 I q t | s i | 2 ≤ V 0 ( 0 ) δ i (28
div.p: Remark 1. From Eq. ( 28) it can be easily concluded that 0
div.formula: I q t | s i | 2 ≤ V 0 (0) δ i
div.p: . According to Theorem 2 , and Eq. ( 28) , it is obvious that the sliding surface and error trajectory asymptotically converge to zero, and this concludes the proof.

Remark 2. In this study, the unknown function d (.) is considered as dynamic uncertainties and disturbances ( Eq. ( 15) ), and in this condition, the stability of the closed-loop system has been proven. Actually, based on presented stability, the proposed control is robust against bounded uncertainties and disturbances. Therefore, the controller has proper performance, and the system converges to the desired value, even though the controller has been fed with incorrect information about slave and master systems.

div.head: Numerical simulations of synchronization
div.p: For numerical simulation, the parameters of the memristor system are set to q = 0.97, a 1 = 10, a 2 = 28, a 3 = 1, a 4 = -2, a 5 = 27, a 6 = -1. We consider that both slave and master systems as hyperchaotic memristor systems with different initial conditions. The initial conditions for slave and master systems are selected as X (0) = [10 10 10 10] T and Y (0) = [ -0.5 -1.5 0 -1.5] T , respectively. Also, the initial condition for controller gains are K i (0) = 0 ( i = 1, 2, 3, 4). In the case which the parameters a 1 , a 2 , a 3 , a 4 , a 5 , a 6 are unknown, according to the Eq. ( 17) and proposed control scheme F i and Ā i are described as:

the parameters ˆ a 1 , ˆ a 2 , ˆ a 3 , ˆ a 4 , ˆ a 5 , ˆ a 6 will be obtained by the proposed adaptive technique and will be used for the control scheme. The coefficients of the adaptive regulator are chosen as

Figs. 6 and7 show the time histories of the synchronization and its error, respectively. As it is obvious, in a short period of time (less than 5 seconds) the slave system is following the master system and the synchronization is completely achieved. The control inputs are shown in Fig. 8 . As it is shown, the control inputs converge to zero in a short period of time. Also, the parameters of the slave system, which are estimated by the proposed adaptive law, are displayed in Fig. 9 . As it is clear, the proposed adaptive regulation scheme adapts well to the system parameters. According to the simulation results, it can be confirmed that the suggested control scheme is effective for the synchronization of uncertain fractional-order systems.

div.head: Voice encryption as an engineering application of the proposed system
div.p: One of the major advantages of chaos-based encryption is its considerablly larger key length and key space in comparison with other methods. Particularly in the case of fractional chaotic systems, fractional orders further increase key length and space. This is explained and used very effectively in image encryption by Wu et al. [ 71 , 72 ]. They have shown that the usage of fractional-order chaotic map greatly improves the key space, and the encryption results will be more secure. Moreover, the fractional-order chaotic map causes only short memory effects and less time increase [73] . According to these benefits, it is a very suitable choice to use fractional-order chaotic systems for encryption applications. In the present study, the main motivation of using fractional calculus for encryption is to obtain a large key space using fractional orders and to increase security in voice encryption applications without memory effects and time increase which remarkably affects the encryption speed. In this section, a voice encryption application of the new fractional-order hyperchaotic memristor oscillator has been performed as an engineering application to show the new system can be used for data security. The block diagram of the voice encryption and decryption are given in Fig. 10 . The system is numerically solved by using the Grünwald-Letnikov algorithm [62] and all state variables are calculated. Then, the states of the system are transformed into 32-bit binary numbers. Also, the original voice is converted into 32-bit binary numbers. After that, each binary number of voice data is XORed the binary numbers of the state variables. In the end, the obtained binary numbers after XOR operation are transformed into floatingpoint numbers. In the decryption process, the encrypted voice data and the numbers calculated by the fractional-order hyperchaotic system are transformed into binary numbers. Then, decryption operation is performed using XOR operation. Finally, the binary numbers are transformed into floating-point numbers and the decrypted voice is acquired.

The original, encrypted and decrypted voice plots respectively are illustrated in Figs. 11 , 12 , and 13 . If the figures are examined, it can be said that the original and the decrypted voice plots are the same, but the encrypted voice is completely different from the original and decrypted voice.

Although the figures of the original and encrypted voices appear to be completely different from each other in the time domain, frequency domain analysis should also be performed to demonstrate that encryption is fully successful. Therefore, the frequency spectra of the original, encrypted and decrypted voice obtained by the FFT method are shown in Figs. 14 , 15 , and 16 , respectively. As seen in the frequency spectrums, the spectrum of the decrypted and original voice are exactly the same. Also, the spectrum of the encrypted voice data has a homogeneous distribution and is totally different from the original and the decrypted voice. In this case, it can be said that the encryption and decryption operations are performed without data loss, and the encryption operation is successful. Thus, it has been shown that the new chaotic system proposed in this study can be used successfully in encryption applications.

Statistical analysis of the encryption and decrypting processes was also performed by four different methods, namely correlation, entropy, root mean square, and root sum of squares. The results are presented in Table 1 . These results show that encryption and decryption processes are quite good. In encryption applications, the completion of the process in a short time is seen as an important parameter. There are methods in the literature using fractional-order chaotic systems. With fractional-order chaotic systems, encryption can take longer in terms of calculation. However, there are studies in the literature that can get results faster [72] . These studies were mostly carried out with fractional-order chaotic maps. However, in this study, since a new fractional-order chaotic system is addressed, encryption was implemented using this system. In this application, all state variables are used to make encryption faster. When iterations are calculated, in each iteration, all of these calculated state variables are used, so the process load and the total time are reduced.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: A new fractional-order hyperchaotic oscillator with a memristor nonlinearity was introduced. Using Lyapunov exponents, bifurcation diagrams, and phase portraits, the dynamical behavior of the proposed system was investigated. It was shown that this system has both unstable and stable fixed points. It was demonstrated that the proposed system goes to chaos through experiencing a cascade of period doublings, and the existence of chaos is verified. After that, by applying the sliding mode concept, the adaptive controller was designed to synchronize the proposed system. The robustness and stability of the proposed fractional-order ASMC technique were proven. Numerical results of synchronization have illustrated that the proposed control scheme correctly estimates the parameters of the system, and the slave system mimics the behaviour of the master system after a short time. The developed control technique can be used to control and synchronize a broad range of uncertain fractional-order systems. Finally, voice encryption was successfully performed to demonstrate an application of the proposed fractional-order hyperchaotic memristor system. The statistical analysis clearly demonstrated the effective performance of the proposed fractional-order system for voice encryption. As a future suggestion, the application of fractional chaotic maps could be considered. Additionally, the complexity analysis (such as C0 complexity analysis) could be performed for the proposed system. Moreover, the proposed control technique can be developed using a fuzzy disturbance observer.

analytic.title: Complete analysis and engineering applications of a megastable nonlinear oscillator
